Subgeometries of projective spaces
Let S=(P,L,I) be a point-line incidence geometry. In case S is a projective space over a finite field, it is clear that every line (and every subspace as well) can be identified with the set of points incident with it. Furthermore, the incidence relation I is then symmetrised containment. To define a subgeometry mathematically, we follow . Let P' \subset P and let L' be a set of subsets of P', such that every line l' \in L' is a subset of exactly one line l \in L. If S'=(P',L',I) is a projective space again, then we call S' a subgeometry of S. A typical example of a subgeometry is a Baer subplane of a projective plane. Mathematically, any subspace of a projective space also induces a subgeometry. Using geometry morphisms, and more particular a function like NaturalEmbeddingBySubField, one can deal in an indirect way with subgeometries. However, using NaturalEmbeddingBySubField is not flexible, and typical problems such as considering a subgeometry determined by a user chosen frame and a subfield, cannot be handled easily using NaturalEmbeddingBySubField. Therefore FinInG provides some functions to naturally construct subgeometries of projective spaces.
Subgeometries of projective spaces
This category is a subcategory of IsProjectiveSpace, and contains all subgeometries of projective spaces. Note that mathmetically spoken, a subspace of a projective space is also a subgeometry. However, in FinInG, subspaces of a projective space are constructed in a category that is not a subcategory of IsProjectiveSpace. Since IsSubgeometryOfProjectiveSpace is a subcategory of IsProjectiveSpace, all operations applicable on projective spaces, are naturally applicable on subgeometries of projective spaces.
A subgeometry of pg This operation returns the subgeometry of pg induced by the standard frame over the subfield subfield. Alternatively, the integer q can be used as the order of the subfield. It is checked whether the user specified subfield is indeed a subfield of the base field of pg. If the subfield equals the base field of pg, the projective space pg is returned.
